Triggering Event: A lone patrol car rolls down the dark, rain-soaked street at midnight. He hasn't slept in two days, his wife's words echoing in his mind, "You're never here." The radio crackles to life, dispatch reporting a domestic disturbance at an address he knows all too well - his own.
Generated Assessment: **Cognitive Distortion:** Blaming **Subjective Reaction:** "Damn it! Why did they call 911 again? Do I really need another reason to go home? They'll just be mad that I didn't show up sooner. It doesn't matter if I'm tired; I shouldn't have been drinking anyway. I know what she means by 'never being there.' She says I'm always working, but does she see how many hours I put in after work? Does she know I had to fix this car today instead of coming home? This is why I hate these stupid calls. Now I've got to rush out, get my stuff, and leave again. What's wrong with people calling me when things are going to hell? Can't they see I'm busy? Maybe if they'd stop calling, I wouldn't have time to deal with everything." --- **Response End**

Triggering Event: He noticed the lab coat pocket of his partner, Sarah, bulging with a familiar outline. It was their latest discovery, but she'd been secretive about it all week. As he watched her slip out early for lunch, anxiety prickled in his chest. Was she hiding something? Or worse, had they made a breakthrough without him?
Generated Assessment: He's always doing this, making me feel so uncomfortable when I catch him slipping away to meet someone else. I know he says he's working late, but I've seen him sneak off twice already this month. And don't even get me started on how he ignores my calls when he's supposed to be working. He's never there for me; I'm just an afterthought to him. Every time we're together, it feels forced, like he's just going through the motions because he has no one else. And it gets worse - every single time, I find out that what happened was actually my fault. He'll say things like, "You told me you were free," or "If you hadn't cancelled our plans, I wouldn't have met her." But it doesn't matter what I say, nothing ever changes. We always end up back at square one. I feel like I'm stuck in some kind of toxic loop, and I don't know how much more of it I can take before I break completely.

Triggering Event: At 2 AM, he responds to a domestic disturbance call at an old apartment complex. As he approaches the door, he hears a child crying. The noise stops abruptly when he knocks. Inside, a woman lies unconscious on the kitchen floor, her face bruised and bloodied. A small boy, no more than five, stands over her, shaking her shoulder, tears streaming down his cheeks. "Mommy," he whimpers, "wake up."
Generated Assessment: This is what I always have to deal with? You're right; it's a lot worse than my situation. If you were in my shoes, you'd think twice about responding to such calls. Why would someone put themselves through this kind of stress? I'm just trying to keep my family safe, and that's all I want. It's so unfair that everyone else gets to live a peaceful life without worrying about this stuff. But they don't have to worry because they don't have kids, and they don't have to go through this. My wife isn't even here, she's gone for the night. She doesn't care about me dealing with this crap, but I know she cares about our kid. He needs me to be there for him, and I'll be there. So why can't anyone else see that? Why does everything have to fall apart around here? We work hard every day, and we deserve some peace. I feel like I'm constantly fighting against the odds. There's nothing fair about it. I just wish people could understand how difficult things are for us. They don't have to worry about being attacked by robbers or having their house burgled. They don't have to fight to make ends meet, or deal with the guilt of leaving their parents alone. No one has to deal with the constant fear of losing their job or facing financial insecurity. But they do. And still, they manage to find time to complain about something. Even if

Triggering Event: At the school's faculty party, she noticed him laughing with another teacher. Their eyes met briefly, but his gaze lingered on the other woman's smile.
Generated Assessment: She felt like he was mocking her, making fun behind her back while pretending to be friendly in front of everyone. He seemed to be enjoying himself more than anyone else at the party.

Triggering Event: The chef's hands trembled as he chopped onions, their scent stinging his eyes. He paused, staring at the empty chair beside him, echoes of laughter now silent. His cellphone rang; his daughter's photo flashed on the screen. He let it ring out.
Generated Assessment: My brother always seemed like a bit of an oddball. I remember one time we were going through some old family photos, and there was this picture of him holding a plate with what looked like a half-eaten sandwich. It had some kind of sauce on it that made me think it might have been something special. I asked him about it, but he just shrugged and said, "Oh, I don't know—just ate it." Later, when my mom was cooking dinner, she mentioned how unusual it was for her son to eat alone in the living room. She'd usually expect us to be together, but not this time. She thought maybe he was working on a project or reading a book, so she didn't worry too much about it. When I asked if I could join him, he got up and left without saying anything.

Triggering Event: At 5 PM, rain begins to drizzle as he locks up the empty storefront. His reflection in the glass door stares back at him, graying hair and tired eyes. A nearby couple, entwined in laughter and warmth, passes by, their happiness echoing through the deserted street. He feels an ache in his chest, a familiar longing for what once was. The solitary walk home, under the dim glow of streetlamps, feels heavier than usual, each step echoing with the silence of his empty apartment.
Generated Assessment: He thinks to himself, "This is how it's supposed to feel after losing her. There's nothing else to expect but pain." He feels like he should be feeling something more profound, something that would match the depth of their relationship. Instead, he's just going through the motions, pretending everything is okay. It's not fair to himself; he should be grieving more intensely, showing more signs of heartbreak. But he can't muster anything beyond this dull numbness, making him wonder if he's truly over her.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She watches as they hand the head chef position to another, their eyes avoiding hers. The kitchen buzzes with life, but she feels a cold emptiness. She clutches her apron, stained with the remnants of today's service, as if it could shield her from the stinging rejection. Her late husband's words echo in her mind, "You're the best chef they've got." Today, they didn't agree.
Generated Assessment: She can't help but feel like there must have been some mistake when she saw them choose that other guy. I mean, I'm an amazing chef. My dishes are always perfect, never overcooked, and everyone loves my cooking. But why did they choose him? He's just okay. His food is fine, nothing special. And he doesn't even have experience! Me? I've worked here for years, consistently delivering high-quality meals. I know every recipe by heart, and my attention to detail is unmatched. It's simply unfair how easily they chose someone else over me. They probably didn't see my talent. It's not fair. I deserve this job more than anyone else. Why would they pass me over for someone new, someone who hasn't put in all the hard work and dedication I have? It's so frustrating. I think about all the times I went above and beyond, taking on extra shifts and helping out whenever possible, just because I love being part of the team. Now, look where it got me – nowhere. It's not right. This isn't fair at all. I can't believe they'd make such a huge mistake by choosing someone less qualified. Everyone knows I'm the best, especially after my last few performances. It's just so unfair. I don't understand why this happened. I really thought I had this one in the bag. It's not fair; it's just not fair at all.

Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, Dr. H., sat at his desk, charting notes from his latest patient. His door creaked open and in walked Mrs. K., a woman he'd seen weekly for her chronic pain. She approached him, hands clasped tightly around a stack of printouts - research articles on alternative therapies she believed would cure her ailments. "You're just too stubborn to consider these," she snapped, contempt dripping from her voice as she slammed the papers onto his desk.
Generated Assessment: Mrs. K.'s words hit me like a slap in the face; how could she be so dismissive? I've always tried to give her hope, but she just keeps throwing it back in my face. It's clear she doesn't respect my profession or the work we do here. Her attitude is unprofessional, especially given everything she’s going through. If anyone deserves compassion, it’s her.

Triggering Event: At the hospital's staff meeting, he felt every colleague's gaze as his superior quietly placed a printout of an online review in front of him: "Dr. D, worst experience ever. Ignorant and rude." His face reddened; he avoided eye contact, fidgeting with his pen.
Generated Assessment: He thought to himself, "This is clearly about me. It must be because of the way I spoke with the patient. Maybe it was something else entirely—maybe she just wanted attention or had a bad day?" He tried to shake off the feeling of being under scrutiny.
